Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, watching my stepdad quietly sip his coffee. He’d been distant lately, and I knew Mom was worried. I wanted to ask if everything was okay, to show him I cared, but I hesitated, unsure if he’d open up to me. Just as I was about to speak, my phone buzzed. It was my best friend, calling. I answered, and immediately heard the strain in their voice. “Can you talk? I really need you right now,” they said, their words trembling. My heart twisted. I glanced at my stepdad, who looked more alone than ever, and then back at my phone, hearing my friend’s muffled sobs. Both needed me—one silently, the other desperately. I felt torn, the weight of their expectations pressing on me from both sides, unsure who needed me more in that moment.
